Original_notes: Improved [circled]; Do not use plow or even the typical subsaharan short handled hoe, but superior (i.e. more effective) technique for soil + climatic conditions though seemingly "crude". See Gamble [?]; The neighboring Mandinka use the hoe but their productivity is not as high as the Wolof, who simply plant without loosening the soil -- this reduces soil erosion, helps maintain nutrients and eliminates certain diseases which are related to not planting early enough (e.g. the Rozette disease among the Mandinka). The Wolof techniques requires some weeding + they have developed an ingenious tool (xiler) for this (See Ames 1959)
animal manure [underlined]
Reverted to nominal[?] "ownerships" of villages head if land allowed to go back to bush
Freeborn caste provided for slave caste
?; not sure of the effect of cash crop production shift
Recent British innovation
individual trees planted
donkeys (1500?)
some appear to be several hundered years old, but villages are abandoned due to soil exhaustion + other[?] factors
Some today but average somewhat less
a few today -- Before the establishment of the Protectorate, the Wolof of the Gambia lived in large fortress "towers". Size?
?; probably not this large in the Gambia, even in the old days
Only one mosque painted in the Gambia
livestock, precious metals, slaves [underlined]; political leader [underlined] + followers
physician [underlined]; muslim teachers - priests - medicine men; often the same individual

(Trade in salt, dried fish, millet, horses)

taxes on economic transactions [underlined]; Rulers -- at least in early days of trade with Europeans -- demanded a fixed share of goods exchanged

?; muslim Wolof in the Gambia were dominated in this way by a serer ruler in Senegal (near Kaolack)
